revision.text:
'''Flame lift-off''' in oil fired pressure jet burners is an unwanted condition in which the [[flame]] and [[Oil burner|burner]] become separated. This condition is most commonly created by excessive [[combustion air]] and often results in the loss of flame as the photo-electric cell fails to register the light of the flame, this in turn results in a safety lockout of the control box.
==Other outcomes== Other outcomes may be experienced: – # There may be delayed [[Combustion|ignition]] as the oil spray is too far forward for the [[electrode]]s to ignite, only when the oil spray has filled the [[combustion chamber]] will the mixture ignite. In this condition it is likely that the excessive volume of unburnt oil will ignite with explosive ignition. # The oil mixture will fail to ignite resulting in safety lockout of the control box. # The oil mixture will ignite but may burn very inefficiently due to excessive air chilling of the oil particles to the point where complete [[combustion]] of the oil is not possible.
== Flame lift-off height == A non-[[Premixed flame|premixed]] jet flame has a tendency to lift off from the burner nozzle position when the jet velocity of the flame is over a critical value of A non-premixed jet flame has a tendency to lift off from the burner [[nozzle]] position when the jet velocity of the flame is over a critical value of <math>U_c</math>.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Demare|first=David|last2=Baillot|first2=Françoise|date=2001-05-30|title=The role of secondary instabilities in the stabilization of a nonpremixed lifted jet flame|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.1386935|journal=Physics of Fluids|language=en|volume=13|issue=9|pages=2662–2670|doi=10.1063/1.1386935|issn=1070-6631|via=}}</ref> With the increasing of the jet velocity, the lifted height will increase and when it’s beyond certain critical height and the flame will be blown off.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2007-07-01|title=Experimental studies of flame stability and emission characteristics of simple LPG jet diffusion flame|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S001623610600439X|journal=Fuel|language=en|volume=86|issue=10-11|pages=1545–1551|doi=10.1016/j.fuel.2006.10.027|issn=0016-2361}}</ref> Therefore, the stability of the lifted flame is an important parameter for basic combustor design. Scholefield and Garside’s theory <ref>{{Cite journal|date=1948-01-01|title=The structure and stability of diffusion flames|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1062289649800134|journal=Symposium on Combustion and Flame, and Explosion Phenomena|language=en|volume=3|issue=1|pages=102–110|doi=10.1016/S1062-2896(49)80013-4|issn=1062-2896}}</ref> claimed that the transition to [[turbulence]] is a prerequisite for the lifted [[diffusion flame]] stabilisation and the flame anchors at a point where the flow is turbulent. Gollahalli <ref>{{Cite journal|date=1988-01-01|title=Structure of attached and lifted gas jet flames in hysteresis region|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0082078488803795|journal=Symposium (International) on Combustion|language=en|volume=21|issue=1|pages=1463–1471|doi=10.1016/S0082-0784(88)80379-5|issn=0082-0784}}</ref> argued that the flame will tend to stable at the position where the local flow velocity balance the normal flame propagation velocity. Navarro-Martinez and Kronenburg <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Navarro-Martinez|first=Salvador|last2=Kronenburg|first2=Andreas|date=2011-01-15|title=Flame Stabilization Mechanisms in Lifted Flames|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10494-010-9320-1|journal=Flow, Turbulence and Combustion|language=en|volume=87|issue=2-3|pages=377–406|doi=10.1007/s10494-010-9320-1|issn=1386-6184}}</ref> have demonstrated that the excessive turbulent stretching at the nozzle leads to the lift-off and they also claimed that auto-ignition can be used to promote the flame stabilisation mechanism. Recently the observation from Kiran and Mishra’s <ref>{{Cite journal|date=2007-07-01|title=Experimental studies of flame stability and emission characteristics of simple LPG jet diffusion flame|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S001623610600439X|journal=Fuel|language=en|volume=86|issue=10-11|pages=1545–1551|doi=10.1016/j.fuel.2006.10.027|issn=0016-2361}}</ref> visual experiment proved the flame lift-off height varies linearly with jet exit velocity. They presented a semi-empirical correlation between the [[Normalization|normalized]]{{disambiguation needed|date=July 2018}} lift-off height to the nozzle exit diameter.
<math>\frac{H_L}{D_f}=1.8*10^{-3}*\frac{U_f}{D_f}</math>
Where, <math>H_f</math>: lift-off height
<math>D_f</math>:diameter of the fuel tube
<math>U_f</math>:fuel jet velocity
In addition to the velocity effect, The [[Stoichiometry|stoichiometric]] burning on the physical mechanism blowout has been investigated by Broadwell et al.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=1985-01-01|title=Blowout of turbulent diffusion flames|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0082078485805154|journal=Symposium (International) on Combustion|language=en|volume=20|issue=1|pages=303–310|doi=10.1016/S0082-0784(85)80515-4|issn=0082-0784}}</ref> and Pitts.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=1989-01-01|title=Assessment of theories for the behavior and blowout of lifted turbulent jet diffusion flames|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0082078489800906|journal=Symposium (International) on Combustion|language=en|volume=22|issue=1|pages=809–816|doi=10.1016/S0082-0784(89)80090-6|issn=0082-0784}}</ref> According to their study on diffusion flame, the fresh air entrained by the [[Vortex|vortices]] structure cools down and over dilutes the flame jet, which leads to the flame extinction.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Combustion]]

[[File:Magneto Resistive Level Sensor.jpg|thumb|Magneto Resistive Level Sensor]] '''Liquid level floats''', also known as '''float balls''', are spherical, cylindrical, oblong or similarly shaped objects, made from either rigid or flexible material, that are [[buoyant]] in water and other liquids. They are non-electrical hardware frequently used as visual sight-indicators for surface demarcation and [[level measurement]]. They may also be incorporated into switch mechanisms or translucent fluid-tubes as a component in monitoring or controlling liquid level.
Liquid level floats, or float switches, use the principle of material buoyancy (differential densities) to follow fluid levels. Solid floats are often made of plastics with a density less than water or other application liquid, and so they float. Hollow floats filled with air are much less dense than water or other liquids, and are appropriate for some applications.<ref>{{cite web|title=Learn More About Liquid Level Floats|url=http://www.globalspec.com/LearnMore/Sensors_Transducers_Detectors/Level_Sensing/Liquid_Level_Floats|publisher=globalspec.com}}</ref>
Stainless Steel Magnetic floats are tubed magnetic floats, used for reed switch activation; they have a hollow tubed connection running through them. These magnetic floats have become standard equipment where strength, corrosion resistance and buoyancy are necessary. They are manufactured by welding two drawn half shells together. The welding process is critical for the strength and durability of the float. The weld is a full penetration weld providing a smoothly finished seam, hardly distinguishable from the rest of the float surface.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mechanical & Magnetic Floats|url=http://www.deeter.co.uk/products/mechanical-magnetic-floats|publisher=deeter.co.uk}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Level sensor]] * [[Float switch]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == {{commonscat|Level_sensors}} * [http://www.instrumentationtoolbox.com/2013/07/ultrasonic-level-sensors-operating.html Ultrasonic Level Sensors] * [http://www.instrumentationtoolbox.com/2013/02/how-capacitance-level-sensor-works.html Capacitance Level Sensors] * [http://www.instrumentationtoolbox.com/2013/03/operating-principle-of-displacer-level.html Displacer Level Sensors] * [http://www.instrumentationtoolbox.com/2013/04/operating-principle-of-radar-level.html Radar Level Sensors]
[[Category:Liquids]] [[Category:Fluid dynamics]] [[Category:Volumetric instruments]] [[Category:Mechanical engineering]]

revision.comment: Category, tidying
revision.text:
'''Fold number''' refers to how many [[double fold (paper testing)|double folds]] that are required to cause rupture of a paper test piece under standardized conditions. Fold number is defined in ISO 5626:1993 as the [[antilogarithm]] of the mean folding endurance:<ref>ISO 5626:1993 Paper – Determination of folding endurance, 3.3</ref>
<math>f=\text{antilog}_{10} \frac{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^n F_i}{n}=10^{\frac{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^n F_i}{n}}</math>
where ''f'' is the fold number, ''F<sub>i</sub>'' is the folding endurance for each test piece and ''n'' is total number of test pieces used.
In the introduction of ISO 5626:1993 it is emphasized that fold number, as defined in that very International Standard, does not equal the mean number of double folds observed. The latter is however still the definition used in some countries.<ref>ISO 5626:1993 Paper – Determination of folding endurance, Introduction.</ref> If the numerical value of the folding endurance is not rounded off, these will however be equal.
In the former Swedish standard SS 152005 ("Pappersordlista") from 1992, with paper related terms defined in Swedish and English, fold number is explained as "the number of double folds which a test strip withstands under specified conditions before a break occurs in the strip"; that is, ''not'' the antilogarithm of the mean folding endurance.
==See also== *[[Folding endurance]] *[[Double fold (paper testing)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Paper}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fold Number}} [[Category:Paper]] [[Category:Materials testing]]

The main '''fuel tax in Australia''' is an [[excise tax]], to which is added a [[Goods and Services Tax (Australia)|Goods and Services Tax]] ("GST"). Both taxes are levied by the federal government. In [[Australia]], like [[Canada]], the GST (in Australia's case of 10%) is applied on top of the fuel excise tax. In some cases, businesses may be entitled to exemptions or rebates for fuel excise tax, including [[tax credits]] and certain excise-free fuel sources.
The double dipping (GST imposed on the excise tax) was fully compensated for by lowering the excise at the time the GST was introduced in 2001{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}}. While the excise stopped being indexed for inflation in 2001, it was reintroduced in 2014 (see History below).
The tax collected is partly used to fund national road infrastructure projects and repair roads, but most of it (approximately 75%) goes into general revenue.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/raise-highway-spend-from-fuel-tax-nrma-20100103-lmq2.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Raise highway spend from fuel tax: NRMA | date=2010-01-02}}</ref>
==Excise tax rates== The excise tax on commonly used fuels in Australia as of October 2018: * A$0.412 per litre on [[unleaded petrol]] fuel (including standard, blended ([[E10 fuel|E10]]) and premium grades) * A$0.412 per litre on [[diesel fuel]] (ultra-low sulphur/conventional) * A$0.134 per litre on [[liquified petroleum gas]] used as fuel ([[autogas]] or LPG as it is commonly known in Australia). * A$0.081 per litre on [[ethanol]] fuel for use as fuel in an internal combustion engine (which can be reduced/removed with grants) * A$0.041 per litre on [[biodiesel]] (which can be reduced/removed with grants)
'''Note:''' Gasoline for use as fuel in an aircraft is taxed at $0.03556 per litre.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ato.gov.au/Business/Excise-and-excise-equivalent-goods/Fuel-excise/Excise-rates-for-fuel/#FuelDef2|publisher=ATO|accessdate=11 October 2016}}</ref>
The federal government increased the fuel excise tax with effect from 10 November 2014 by restoring CPI indexation to the tax every six months, on 1 February and 1 August.<ref>[https://www.ato.gov.au/Business/Fuel-schemes/In-detail/Fuel-tax-credits---for-GST-registered-businesses/Overview/Fuel-tax-credits---changes-from-1-July-2014/?anchor=Ratesandtools#Ratesandtools ATO - Fel Schemes] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821024022/https://www.ato.gov.au/Business/Fuel-schemes/In-detail/Fuel-tax-credits---for-GST-registered-businesses/Overview/Fuel-tax-credits---changes-from-1-July-2014/?anchor=Ratesandtools#Ratesandtools |date=August 21, 2014 }}</ref> From that date the fuel excise tax increased to 38.6 cents per litre.
The excise tax on commonly used fuels in Australia as of 1 October 2018 is: * A$0.412 per litre on unleaded petrol fuel (including standard, blended (E10) and premium grades) * A$0.412 per litre on diesel fuel * A$0.134 per litre on liquified petroleum gas used as fuel (autogas or LPG as it is commonly known in Australia) In addition all fuels are subject to 10% Goods and Services Tax(GST).
'''Note:''' Gasoline for use as fuel in an aircraft is taxed at $0.03556 per litre.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ato.gov.au/business/excise-and-excise-equivalent-goods/fuel-excise/excise-rates-for-fuel/|title=Excise rates for fuel|publisher=ATO|accessdate=24 July 2016}}</ref>
There are also a number of various [[grant (money)|grants]] and [[incentive schemes]] involving tax credits and rebates that generally apply to businesses or industries that rely heavily on the use of fuels, such as [[transport]] and [[aviation]]. There are also rebates that encourage the production and importation of [[clean fuels]].
== History == The Commonwealth introduced a twice yearly indexation for [[Consumer Price Index]] of fuel excise taxes in 1983. The states used to levy fuel franchise fees until the [[High Court of Australia]] in ''[[Ha v New South Wales]]'' (1997) ruled that a licence fee based on the value of tobacco was unconstitutional, as it was an excise tax that only the Commonwealth can levy. The ruling brought into doubt the revenues of the states. In consequence, the federal government introduced a fuel excise tax and gave the revenue to the states.
In 2001, the [[Howard Government]] adjusted the excise rates because of the introduction of the [[Goods and Services Tax (Australia)|GST]] and stopped the automatic indexation of the fuel excise tax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/C2004B00862| title= Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2001|last=Ireland|first=Ian|date=2001-06-04|work=Bills Digest No. 142 2000-01|publisher=Department of the Parliamentary Library|accessdate=2009-10-01}}</ref>
The second phase of the Australian Fuel Tax Credits Scheme came into effect on 1 July 2008. Under these changes, all off-road business use of fuel became eligible for subsidies. In other words, businesses that do not run large vehicle fleets but consume large amounts of fuel in business processes (such as mining, manufacturing, construction, plant operations) became eligible for a fuel tax credit.
[[Queensland]] used to provide an 8.354c/L subsidy on most fuels sold in the state, including on unleaded, blended unleaded, LPG and ethanol. The subsidy reflected the lower franchise fee Queensland charged compared to other states prior to 1997. This was usually reflected by an 8.354c/L price difference at the pump, as the subsidy was paid directly to retailers. The subsidy was removed from 1 July 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.treasury.qld.gov.au/services/grants/fuel.shtml |title=Fuel Subsidy Scheme |date=2009-09-30 |publisher=Queensland Treasury |accessdate=2009-10-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090810091220/http://www.treasury.qld.gov.au/services/grants/fuel.shtml |archivedate=2009-08-10 |df= }}</ref>
The indexation of the fuel excise tax was reintroduced by the [[Abbott Government]] from 10 November 2014, with indexation being effected twice a year, on 1 February and 1 August.
== See also == * [[Taxation in Australia]]
== External links == * [http://law.ato.gov.au/atolaw/view.htm?docid=PAC/BL030002/1 Excise Tax Rates in Australia] * [http://fueltaxinquiry.treasury.gov.au/content/backgnd/002.asp Fuel Tax Inquiry]
== References == {{reflist}} {{Economy of Australia}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fuel Taxes In Australia}} [[Category:Taxation in Australia]] [[Category:Fuel taxes|Australia]] [[Category:Energy in Australia]]

revision.comment: Add: bibcode, website. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[User:AquaDTRS|AquaDTRS]]
revision.text:
The '''GLA'''ss '''S'''pherical '''T'''okamak (or '''GLAST''') is a name given to a set of small [[Spherical tokamak|spherical tokamaks]] (i.e. [[magnetic confinement fusion]] reactors) located in [[Islamabad]], [[Pakistan]]. They were developed by the [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission]] (PAEC) as part of the National Tokamak Fusion Program (NTFP) in 2008{{cite web|last=Griffith|first=Sabina|title=Pakistan launches national fusion program|url=http://www.iter.org/newsline/15/1025|website=ITER Organization|publisher=ITER Organization|accessdate=5 January 2013}} and are primarily used for teaching and training purposes. == GLAST-I & GLAST-II == {{Fusion devices |name = GLAST-I & GLAST-II |image = |imagetitle = |type = [[Spherical tokamak|Spherical]] |operation = |major radius = 15 cm |minor radius = 9 cm |field = 0.1 - 0.4 [[Tesla (unit)|T]] |heating = 300 - 400 [[Electron volt|eV]] |current = 50 [[kiloampere|kA]] |time = 10 [[milliseconds|ms]] (pulsed) |location = [[Islamabad]], [[Pakistan]] }} The first two tokamaks developed were named GLAST-I and GLAST-II. Both devices have similar principles of operation and consist of an insulated vacuum vessel made of [[Pyrex|pyrex glass]]. However, the central tube of GLAST-I is made of [[steel]], while that of GLAST-II is made of glass.{{Cite journal|last=Hussain|first=S.|last2=Sadiq|first2=M.|last3=Shah|first3=S. I. W.|last4=Team|first4=GLAST|date=2015|title=Estimation of Electron Temperature on Glass Spherical Tokamak (GLAST)|url=http://stacks.iop.org/1742-6596/591/i=1/a=012009|journal=Journal of Physics: Conference Series|language=en|volume=591|issue=1|pages=012009|doi=10.1088/1742-6596/591/1/012009|issn=1742-6596|bibcode=2015JPhCS.591a2009H}} Studies were done in GLAST-II to identify the mechanism responsible for current generation during the start-up phase of tokamak discharge.{{Cite journal|last=Hussain et al.|first=S.|date=21 Jan 2016|title=Initial Plasma Formation in the GLAST-II Spherical Tokamak|journal=Journal of Fusion Energy|language=en|volume=35|issue=3|pages=529–537|doi=10.1007/s10894-015-0052-z|issn=0164-0313}} === Diagnostics === Plasma diagnostics including [[Langmuir_probe#Triple_probe|Langmuir triple probes]]Qayyum et al., Time-resolved measurement of plasma parameters by means of triple probe, Review of Scientific Instruments 84, 123502 (2013).Qayyum et al., Triple-probe Diagnostic Measurements in Plasma of GLAST Spherical Tokamak, J Fusion Energ, 35 (2016) 205-213., emissive probes{{Cite journal|last=Qayyum|first=A.|last2=Ahmad|first2=S.|last3=Deeba|first3=F.|last4=Hussain|first4=S.|date=Nov 2016|title=Plasma measurements in pulse discharge with resistively heated emissive probe|journal=High Temperature|language=en|volume=54|issue=6|pages=802–807|doi=10.1134/s0018151x16060158|issn=0018-151X}} and [[Optical Emission Spectroscopy]] systems were developed to measure basic [[plasma parameters]] such as electron temperature, electron number density, floating potential and impurity content in the discharge. The triple probe is capable of recording instantaneous plasma characteristics. Plasma current is then enhanced up to 5 kA by applying a small vertical magnetic field that provides additional plasma heating and shaping. The evolution of [[Electron cyclotron resonance|electron cyclotron heating]] (ECH)-assisted pre-ionization and subsequent current formation phases in one shot are well envisioned by probe measurements. The probe data seem to correlate with microwave absorption and subsequent light emission. Intense fluctuations in the current formation phase advocate for efficient equilibrium and feedback control systems. Moreover, the emergence of some strong impurity [[nitrogen]] lines in the [[emission spectrum]] even after few shots propose crucial need for improvement in the base vacuum level. A noticeable change in the profile's shape of floating potential, electron temperature, ion saturation current (Isat) and light emission is observed with changing [[hydrogen]] fill pressure and vertical field.{{Cite journal|last=Hussain|first=S|last2=Qayyum|first2=A|last3=Ahmad|first3=Z|last4=Ahmad|first4=S|last5=Khan|first5=R|last6=Naveed|first6=M A|last7=Ali|first7=R|last8=Deeba|first8=F|last9=Vorobyov|first9=G M and GLAST Team|date=20 Jun 2017|title=Electrical and optical measurements in the early hydrogen discharge of GLAST-III|url=http://stacks.iop.org/1009-0630/19/i=8/a=085103?key=crossref.39ad8b1492b72d411003d01fcc372815|journal=Plasma Science and Technology|volume=19|issue=8|pages=085103|doi=10.1088/2058-6272/aa68db|issn=1009-0630|via=|bibcode=2017PlST...19h5103H}} The main discharge has been supported by microwave pre-ionization in the presence of optimized resonant toroidal magnetic field (TF). While optimizing the magnetic field, theoretical and experimental results of the TF profile are compared using a combination of fast and slow capacitor banks. The magnetic field produced by poloidal field (PF) coils are compared with theoretically predicted values. It is found that calculated results are in good agreement with experimental measurement. An economical [[microwave]] source of 2.45 ± 0.02 GHz is fabricated using a [[Cavity magnetron|magnetron]] obtained from a household microwave oven. Pulsed-mode operation of the magnetron is achieved through certain necessary modifications in the circuit. The magnetic field is upgraded to enhance the microwave power, where an additional [[electromagnet]] is introduced around the magnetron cavity that confines the fast moving electrons. This modified microwave source is sufficient to achieve the breakdown in GLAST-II with improved plasma current of 5kA.{{Cite journal|last=Khan|first=R.|last2=Nazir|first2=M.|last3=Ali|first3=A.|last4=Hussain|first4=S.|last5=Vorobyev|first5=G.M.|date=Jan 2018|title=Development of microwave pre-ionization source for GLAST tokamak|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0920379617308992|journal=Fusion Engineering and Design|volume=126|pages=10–14|doi=10.1016/j.fusengdes.2017.11.002|issn=0920-3796|via=}} == GLAST-III == {{Fusion devices |name = GLAST-III |image = |imagetitle = |type = [[Spherical tokamak|Spherical]] |operation = |major radius = 20 cm |minor radius = 10 cm |field = 2.6 [[Tesla (unit)|T]] (central)
1 [[Tesla (unit)|T]] (toroidal) |heating = |current = 2 [[kiloampere|kA]] |time = 1 [[milliseconds|ms]] (pulsed) |location = [[Islamabad]], [[Pakistan]] }} GLAST-III is an upgraded version of the GLAST-I and GLAST-II designs which features a larger vessel diameter and a larger central bore for the placement of diagnostic tools such as [[Rogowski coil|Rogowski coils]] and [[Flux loop|flux loops]].{{Cite journal|last=Qayyum|first=A.|last2=Deeba|first2=Farah|last3=Usman Naseer|first3=M.|last4=Ahmad|first4=S.|last5=Javed|first5=M.A.|last6=Hussain|first6=S.|date=Sep 2018|title=A photodiode array and Langmuir probe for characterizing plasma in GLAST-III tokamak device|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0263224118303567|journal=Measurement|volume=125|pages=56–62|doi=10.1016/j.measurement.2018.04.075|issn=0263-2241|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Ahmad|first=Zahoor|last2=Ahmad|first2=S.|last3=Naveed|first3=M. A.|last4=Deeba|first4=F.|last5=Javeed|first5=M. Aqib|last6=Batool|first6=S.|last7=Hussain|first7=S.|last8=Vorobyov|first8=G. M.|date=2017|title=Optimization of magnetic field system for glass spherical tokamak GLAST-III|url=http://stacks.iop.org/1402-4896/92/i=4/a=045601|journal=Physica Scripta|language=en|volume=92|issue=4|pages=045601|doi=10.1088/1402-4896/aa6458|issn=1402-4896|bibcode=2017PhyS...92d5601A}} === Diagnostics === GLAST-III retained most of the diagnostics used in GLAST-I and GLAST-II, but a newly developed spectroscopic system based on linear [[photodiode]] array was installed on the upgraded GLAST-III for spatial and temporal characterization of hydrogen discharge through light emission. The spectral range of each silicon photodiode is from 300 nm to 1100 nm with response time of 10 ns and active area of 5 mm2 (circular). The light from the plasma is collected through holes along 4 line-of-sight channels with spatial resolution of about 5 cm passing from entire poloidal cross section. The photodiode's signals located at position of 10 and 14 cm from inboard side show fluctuations in the central plasma region. Moreover, the sequence of plasma lighting shows that plasma instigates from the central resonant field region and then expands outwards. At lower pressure, outboard movement of the plasma is slower suggesting better plasma confinement. In addition to photodiode array, an [[optical spectrometer]] (Ocean Optics HR2000+) has been used to record the visible spectrum over the selected range (597–703 nm) with a spectral resolution of 0.15 nm. The studies have been conducted during initial phase of plasma formation for two different hydrogen gas fill pressures. The triple probe is used to get time-resolved information on plasma parameters in the edge region. The time evolution of whole discharge including microwave pre-ionization phase and current formation phase has been demonstrated by temporal profiles of light emission and plasma floating potential. ==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading == * {{cite web|title=Pakistan launches national fusion program|url=http://www.iter.org/newsline/15/1025|website=ITER|publisher=International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor|accessdate=6 January 2013}} {{fusion experiments}} [[Category:Fusion power]] [[Category:Fusion reactors]] [[Category:Nuclear technology in Pakistan]] [[Category:Plasma physics]] [[Category:Science and technology in Pakistan]] [[Category:Tokamaks]]

revision.comment: +plasma stub
revision.text:
'''GYRO''' is a computational [[plasma physics]] code developed and maintained at [[General Atomics]]. It solves the 5-D coupled [[Gyrokinetics|gyrokinetic]]-Maxwell equations using a combination of [[finite difference]], [[finite element method|finite element]] and [[spectral method]]s. Given plasma equilibrium data, GYRO can determine the rate of turbulent transport of particles, momentum and energy.
==See also== *[[List of plasma (physics) articles]]
==External links== * [http://fusion.gat.com/theory/Gyro GYRO Homepage at General Atomics]
[[Category:Computational physics]] [[Category:Physics software]] [[Category:Plasma physics]] [[Category:Tokamaks]]
{{plasma-stub}}

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=December 2006}} {{confusing|date=June 2016}} '''Glow fuel''' is a [[fuel]] source used in [[model engine]]s – generally the same or similar fuels can be used in [[Physical model|model]] [[model aircraft|airplanes]], [[Radio-controlled helicopter|helicopters]], [[Radio-controlled car|cars]] and [[Model boats|boats]]. Glow fuel can be burned by very simple two-stroke engines or by more complicated four-stroke engines, and these engines can provide impressive amounts of power for their very small size. Glow fuel is primarily for two-stroke engines with the need for oil mixed in the fuel and limited exhaust and fuel/air between cycles. [[Top Fuel]] race cars with 4-stroke engines may also use glow fuel, but in this case it does not contain appreciable oil.
==Name== Other commonly used names are '''nitro''' or just '''model fuel'''. Note that the '''nitro''' name is generally inaccurate, as [[nitromethane]] is usually not the primary ingredient, and in fact many glow fuels, especially the so-called "FAI" type, named for the [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]], which requires such fuel in some forms of aeromodeling competition, contain no nitromethane at all.
==Ingredients== Glow fuel is a mixture of [[methanol]], [[nitromethane]], and [[oil]].
Methanol is the primary ingredient as it provides the bulk of the fuel, and is needed as a solvent for the other ingredients. The presence of methanol vapor causes the [[Model_engine#Glowplug_engines|glow plug]] found in model engines to heat via a catalytic reaction with the platinum wire and glow.
Nitromethane is added to the methanol to increase power and to make the engine easier to tune. Typically glow fuel is about 0-30% nitromethane. While higher concentrations can result in better engine performance, use of highly concentrated nitromethane is rare because of its cost. Although a given amount of nitromethane contains less energy than the same amount of methanol, it increases the amount of available oxygen in the combustion chamber, which allows the engine to draw in less air and more fuel. The increased amount of fuel increases power output and also helps cool the engine. For racing use, the nitromethane content can be increased to the range of 30%-65%.
Nitromethane is often difficult to obtain in many countries, so in these countries glow fuel typically has no nitromethane at all, which is generally not detrimental to engine longevity.
==Lubrication== Most model engines require oil to be included with the fuel as a lubricant since the engine has no independent oiling capability. Model engine fuel is typically 8-22% oil, with the higher percentages run in older design two-stroke glow engines that use bushings for the crankshaft bearings. The most commonly used lubricants are [[castor oil]] and synthetic oils, and many glow fuels include a mixture of the two. The oils included in glow fuel generally are not burned by the engine, and are expelled out the [[exhaust system|exhaust]] of the engine. This also helps the engine dissipate heat, as the oil emitted is generally hot.
[[Four stroke]] model engines, since they are generally designed to be simple powerplants while still incorporating the usual camshaft, rocker arms and poppet valves of larger sized four stroke engines, are generally meant to use glow ignition and their fuel. Often, the oil percentage for four stroke glow fuel can be lowered from the 18–20% figure used for some two-stroke engines, down to as low as a 12–15%, but use of such low-lubricant fuel can also mandate the need for a small amount of castor oil in the mix, and mandates setting the high-speed fuel mixture carefully by using a handheld digital [[tachometer]] to check engine speed to avoid over-leaning of the fuel mixture.
Glow engines generally have to be run slightly rich with a higher fuel/air ratio than is ideal in order to keep the engine cool. The uncombusted fuel in the exhaust carries heat, providing the cooling effect. Because of this, vehicles with glow engines generally get coated with lots of oil. Almost all the oil mixed with the fuel is unconsummed and comes out the exhaust, as well as some of the nitromethane and methanol as well. This requires some cleaning.
The nitromethane in many glow fuel blends can cause corrosion of metal parts in model engines, especially four-stroke designs, due to the [[nitric acid]] residue formed from combustion of nitromethane-containing fuel, making the use of a so-called "after-run oil" a common practice after a model flying session with a four-stroke glow-engine-powered model.
Glow fuel is not difficult to make, and so many modelers mix their own to save money, but some of the ingredients are flammable or explosive and so can be dangerous, especially in large quantities. Most modelers buy their glow fuel premixed.
==Alternatives== Nitromethane is sometimes replaced or supplemented by [[nitroethane]]. [[Propylene oxide]] is sometimes added in small percentages. Another form of model fuel, for small compression ignition engines, is called "Diesel Fuel", which generally consists of [[kerosene]], [[ether]], oil and some sort of ignition improver, usually [[amyl nitrate]] or [[isopropyl nitrate]], it is in no way related to the automotive fuel of the same name.
==See also== * [[Glow plug (model engine)]] * [[Model engine]]
==External links==
* [http://www3.telus.net/dieselcombat/diesel_fuel.htm model diesel fuel]
[[Category:Fuels]]

revision.comment: authorlink2=[[Johan Rockström]]
revision.text:
{{expert needed|reason=what the differences are, if any, between the meaning of the terms "[[Icehouse Earth]]", "[[Ice Age]]", and "[[Glacial Period]]"|talk=Difference Between "Icehouse Earth", "Ice Age", and "Glacial Period"|Environment|date=April 2013}} [[File:GlaciationsinEarthExistancelicenced annotated.jpg|thumb|600px|right|Timeline of the five known great glaciations, shown in blue. The periods in between depict greenhouse conditions.]] Throughout the Phanerozoic [[history of the Earth]], the planet's climate has been fluctuating between two dominant [[climate state]]s: the '''greenhouse Earth''' and the '''icehouse Earth'''.<ref>{{Cite journal | year=2010 | author=Ian Harding | title=Greenhouse to Icehouse: arctic climate change 55–33 million years ago | url=http://www.esta-uk.net/index_htm_files/TES%20Issue%2035%201.pdf#page=33 | format=PDF | publisher= Teaching Earth Sciences | volume= 35 | issue= 1 | quote= "A striking picture of Arctic climatic perturbations has started to emerge from these cores, specifically three major events (Thomas et al., 2006; Zachos et al., 2001): the Palaeocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM), the mid-Eocene [[Azolla Event]] and the [[Greenhouse effect|greenhouse]] to icehouse transition at the Eocene-Oligocene boundary (EOB)."}}</ref> These two climate states last for millions of years and should not be confused with [[glacial period|glacial]] and [[interglacial]] periods, which occur only during an icehouse period and tend to last less than 1 million years. There are [[Timeline of glaciation|five known great glaciation]]s in Earth's climate history; the main factors involved in changes of the [[paleoclimate]] are believed to be the concentration of atmospheric [[carbon dioxide]], changes in the [[Earth's orbit]], and oceanic and [[orogenic]] changes due to [[Plate tectonics|tectonic plate dynamics]]. Greenhouse and icehouse periods have profoundly shaped the [[evolution]] of life on Earth.
==Greenhouse Earth== ===Overview of greenhouse Earth=== A "greenhouse Earth" or "hothouse Earth" is a period in which there are no continental [[glacier]]s whatsoever on the planet, the levels of carbon dioxide and other [[greenhouse gas]]es (such as [[water vapor]] and [[methane]]) are high, and [[sea surface temperature]]s (SSTs) range from 28 °C (82.4 °F) in the [[tropics]] to 0 °C (32 °F) in the [[polar region]]s.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Price|first=Gregory|author2=Paul J. Valdes |author3=Bruce W. Sellwood |title=A comparison of GCM simulated Cretaceous 'greenhouse' and 'icehouse climates: implications for the sedimentary record|journal=Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology|year=1998|volume=142|pages=123–138|doi=10.1016/s0031-0182(98)00061-3|bibcode=1998PPP...142..123P}}</ref>
This state should not be confused with a hypothetical ''hothouse earth'', which is an irreversible tipping point corresponding to the ongoing [[runaway greenhouse effect]] on [[Venus]].<ref>{{cite journal | last=Steffen | first=Will | last2=Rockström | first2=Johan |authorlink2=Johan Rockström | last3=Richardson | first3=Katherine | last4=Lenton | first4=Timothy M. | last5=Folke | first5=Carl | last6=Liverman | first6=Diana | last7=Summerhayes | first7=Colin P. | last8=Barnosky | first8=Anthony D. | last9=Cornell | first9=Sarah E. | last10=Crucifix | first10=Michel | last11=Donges | first11=Jonathan F. | last12=Fetzer | first12=Ingo | last13=Lade | first13=Steven J. | last14=Scheffer | first14=Marten | last15=Winkelmann | first15=Ricarda | last16=Schellnhuber | first16=Hans Joachim | title=Trajectories of the Earth System in the Anthropocene | journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | publisher=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | date=2018-08-06 | issn=0027-8424 | doi=10.1073/pnas.1810141115 | page=201810141 | ref=harv }}</ref> The [[IPCC]] states that "a 'runaway greenhouse effect'—analogous to [that of] Venus—appears to have virtually no chance of being induced by [[Human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] activities."<ref>http://www.ipcc.ch/meetings/session31/inf3.pdf</ref>
===Causes of greenhouse Earth=== There are several theories as to how a greenhouse Earth can come about. The geological record shows CO<sub>2</sub> and other greenhouse gases are abundant during this time. [[Tectonic movement]]s were extremely active during the more well-known greenhouse ages (such as 368 million years ago in the [[Paleozoic]] Era). Because of [[Divergent boundary|continental rifting]] ([[continental plate]]s moving away from each other) [[volcanic]] activity becomes more prominent, producing more CO<sub>2</sub> and heating up the Earth's atmosphere.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Norris|first=Richard D.|author2=Karen L. Bice |author3=Elizabeth A. Magno |author4=Paul A. Wilson |title=Jiggling the tropical thermostat in the Cretaceous hothouse|journal=Geology|year=2002|volume=30|pages=299–302|bibcode = 2002Geo....30..299N |doi = 10.1130/0091-7613(2002)030<0299:JTTTIT>2.0.CO;2 }}</ref> Earth is more commonly placed in a greenhouse state throughout the epochs, and the Earth has been in this state for approximately 80% of the past 500 million years, which makes understanding the direct causes somewhat difficult.<ref name="SpicerCorfield1992">{{cite journal|last=Spicer|first=Robert A.|author2=Richard M. Corfield |title=A review of terrestrial and marine climates in the Cretaceous with implications for modelling the 'Greenhouse Earth'|journal=Geological Magazine |year=1992|volume=129|issue=2|pages=169–180|doi=10.1017/s0016756800008268|bibcode=1992GeoM..129..169S}}</ref>
==Icehouse Earth== {{Life timeline}} {{see also|Ice age|Timeline of glaciation}}
===Overview of icehouse Earth=== An "icehouse Earth" is the earth as it experiences an [[ice age]]. Unlike a greenhouse Earth, an icehouse Earth has [[ice sheet]]s present, and these sheets wax and wane throughout times known as [[glacial periods]] and [[interglacial|interglacial period]]s. During an icehouse Earth, greenhouse gases tend to be less abundant, and temperatures tend to be cooler globally. The Earth is currently in an icehouse stage,<ref name="Montanez-p24-27">{{cite journal|last=Montanez|first=Isabel|author2=G.S. Soreghan|title=Earth's Fickle Climate: Lessons Learned from Deep-Time Ice Ages|journal=Geotimes|date=March 2006|volume=51|pages=24–27}}</ref> as ice sheets are present on both [[Geographical pole|pole]]s and glacial periods have occurred at regular intervals over the past million years.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Monnin |first1=E. |last2=Indermühle |first2=A. |last3=Dällenbach |first3=A. |last4=Flückiger |first4=J. |last5=Stauffer |first5=B. |last6=Stocker |first6=T. F. |last7=Raynaud |first7=D. |last8=Barnola |first8=J.-M. |title=Atmospheric CO2 Concentrations over the Last Glacial Termination |year=2001 |journal=Science |volume=291 |number=5501 |pages=112–114 |doi=10.1126/science.291.5501.112 |pmid=11141559|bibcode=2001Sci...291..112M }}</ref>
===Causes of icehouse Earth=== The causes of an icehouse state are much debated, because not much is really known about the transition periods between greenhouse to icehouse climates and what could make the climate so different. One important aspect is clearly the decline of CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere, possibly due to low volcanic activity.
Other important issues are the movement of the tectonic plates and the opening and closing of oceanic gateways.<ref name="Smith-p337-340">{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Alan G.|author2=Kevin T. Pickering|title=Oceanic gateways as a critical factor to initiate icehouse Earth|journal=Journal of the Geological Society|year=2003|volume=160|pages=337–340|doi=10.1144/0016-764902-115}}</ref> These seem to play a crucial part in icehouse Earths because they can bring forth cool waters from very deep water circulations that could assist in creating ice sheets or thermal isolation of areas. Examples of this occurring are the opening of the [[Oligocene#The opening of the Tasman Gateway|Tasmanian gateway]] 36.5 million years ago that separated [[Australia]] and [[Antarctica]] and which is believed to have set off the [[Cenozoic]] icehouse,<ref name="Exon-p11-17">{{cite journal|last=Exon|first=N.|author2=J. Kennet |author3=M. Malone |title=The Opening of the Tasmanian Gateway Drove Cenozoic Paleoclimate: Results of Leg 189|journal=JOIDES|year=2000|volume=26|pages=11–17}}</ref> and the creation of the [[Drake Passage]] 32.8 million years ago by the separation of [[South America]] and [[Antarctica]],<ref>{{cite journal|last=Latimer|first=J.C.|author2=G. M. Filipelli|title=Eocene to Miocene terrigenous inputs and export production; geochemical evidence from ODP Leg 177 Site 190|journal=Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology|year=2002|volume=182|pages=151–164|doi=10.1016/s0031-0182(01)00493-x|bibcode=2002PPP...182..151L}}</ref> though it was believed by other scientists that this did not come into effect until around 23 million years ago.<ref name="Exon-p11-17" /> The closing of the [[Isthmus of Panama]] and the [[Geology of Indonesia#Indonesian Seaway|Indonesian seaway]] approximately 3 or 4 million years ago may have been a major cause for our current icehouse state.<ref name="Smith-p337-340" /> For the icehouse climate, tectonic activity also creates mountains, which are produced by one continental plate colliding with another one and continuing forward. The revealed fresh [[soil]]s act as [[scrubber]]s of carbon dioxide, which can significantly affect the amount of this greenhouse gas in the atmosphere. An example of this is the collision between the [[Indian subcontinent]] and the [[Asia]]n continent, which created the [[Himalayas|Himalayan Mountains]] about 50 million years ago.
=== Glacials and interglacials === {{main|Glacial period|Interglacial}} Within icehouse states, there are "[[glacial period|glacial]]" and "[[interglacial]]" periods that cause ice sheets to build up or retreat. The causes for these glacial and interglacial periods are mainly variations in the movement of the earth around the [[Sun]].<ref name="Broecker-p49-56">{{cite journal|last=Broecker|first=Wallace S.|author2=George H. Denton|title=What Drives Glacial Cycles|journal=Scientific American|date=January 1990|pages=49–56}}</ref> The astronomical components, discovered by the Serbian geophysicist [[Milutin Milanković]] and now known as [[Milankovitch cycles]], include the [[axial tilt]] of the Earth, the [[orbital eccentricity]] (or shape of the [[orbit]]) and the [[precession]] (or wobble) of the [[Earth's rotation|Earth's spin]]. The tilt of the axis tends to fluctuate between 21.5° to 24.5° and back every 41,000 years on the vertical axis. This change actually affects the [[seasonality]] upon the earth, since more or less [[Insolation|solar radiation]] hits certain areas of the planet more often on a higher tilt, while less of a tilt would create a more even set of seasons worldwide. These changes can be seen in ice cores, which also contains information that shows that during glacial times (at the maximum extension of the ice sheets), the atmosphere had lower levels of carbon dioxide. This may be caused by the increase or redistribution of the [[acid]]/[[Base (chemistry)|base]] balance with [[bicarbonate]] and [[carbonate]] [[ion]]s that deals with [[alkalinity]]. During an Icehouse, only 20% of the time is spent in interglacial, or warmer times.<ref name="Broecker-p49-56" />
=== Snowball earth === {{main|Snowball Earth}} A "[[snowball earth]]" is the complete opposite of greenhouse Earth, in which the earth's surface is completely frozen over; however, a snowball earth technically does not have continental ice sheets like during the icehouse state. "The Great Infra-[[Cambrian]] Ice Age" has been claimed to be the host of such a world, and in 1964, the scientist [[W. Brian Harland]] brought forth his discovery of indications of glaciers in [[low latitudes]] (Harland and Rudwick). This became a problem for Harland because of the thought of the "Runaway Snowball Paradox" (a kind of [[Snowball effect]]) that, once the earth enters the route of becoming a snowball earth, it would never be able to leave that state. However, in 1992 {{ill|Joseph Kirschvink|display=1|de}} brought up a solution to the paradox. It is believed that since the continents at this time were huddled at the low and mid-latitudes that there was a great cooling event by planetary [[albedo]], or reflection of the earth’s surface. Kirschvink explained that the way to get out of the snowball could be connected to carbon dioxide, since volcanic activity would not halt, and that the buildup and lack of "[[scrubber|scrubbing]]" of this carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, that the earth would return to a greenhouse state. Some scientists believe that the end of the snowball Earth caused an event known as the [[Cambrian Explosion]], which produced the beginnings of [[multi-cellular]] life.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Maruyama|first=S.|author2=M. Santosh|title=Models on Snowball Earth and Cambrian explosion: A synopsis|journal=Gondwana Research|year=2008|volume=14|pages=22–32|doi=10.1016/j.gr.2008.01.004|bibcode=2008GondR..14...22M}}</ref> However some biologists claim that a complete snowball Earth could not have happened since [[photosynthetic]] life would not have survived underneath many meters of ice without [[sunlight]]. However, it has been observed that, even under meters of thick ice around Antarctica, sunlight shows through. Most scientists{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} today believe that a "hard" Snowball Earth, one completely covered by ice, is probably impossible. However, a "slushball earth", with points of openings near the [[equator]], is possible.
Recent studies may have again complicated the idea of a snowball earth. In October 2011, a team of French researchers announced that the carbon dioxide during the last speculated "snowball earth" may have been lower than originally stated, which provides a challenge in finding out how Earth was able to get out of its state and if it were a snowball or slushball.<ref>{{cite web|last=CNRS|first=Delegation Paris Michel-Ange|title=Snowball Earth's hypothesis challenged|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/10/000102083450.htm|work=ScienceDaily|accessdate=24 November 2011}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Transitions==
===Causes=== The [[Eocene]], which occurred between 53 and 49 million years ago, was the Earth's warmest temperature period for 100 million years.<ref>{{cite web|last=Herath|first=Anuradha K.|title=From Greenhouse to icehouse|url=http://www.astrobio.net./exclusive/3320/from-greenhouse-to-icehouse|work=Astrobio|accessdate=28 October 2011}}</ref> However, this "super-greenhouse" eventually became an icehouse by the late Eocene. It was believed that the decline of CO<sub>2</sub> caused this change, though there are possible [[positive feedback]]s, or added influence that contributes to the cooling.
The best record we have for a transition from an icehouse to a greenhouse period where plant life exists is during the [[Permian]] [[Age (geology)|epoch]] that occurred around 300 million years ago. In 40 million years a major transition took place, causing the Earth to change from a moist, icy planet where [[rainforest]]s covered the tropics, into a hot, dry, and windy location where little could survive. Professor [[Isabel P. Montañez]] of [[University of California, Davis]], who has researched this time period, found the climate to be "highly unstable" and "marked by dips and rises in carbon dioxide".<ref name="UCDavis">{{cite web|last=University of California-Davis|title=A Bumpy Shift from Ice House to Greenhouse|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/01/070104144854.htm|work=ScienceDaily|accessdate=4 November 2011}}</ref>
===Impacts=== The Eocene-Oligocene transition, the latest transition occurring approximately 34 million years ago, resulted in rapid global temperature decrease, the glaciation of Antarctica and a series of biotic extinction events. The most dramatic species turnover event associated with this time period is the [[Grande Coupure]], a period which saw the replacement of European tree-dwelling and leaf-eating mammal species by migratory species from Asia.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Prothero|first=D. R.|date=1994-01-01|title=The Late Eocene-Oligocene Extinctions|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1146/annurev.ea.22.050194.001045|journal=Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences|volume=22|issue=1|pages=145–165|doi=10.1146/annurev.ea.22.050194.001045|bibcode=1994AREPS..22..145P}}</ref>
===Research=== The science of [[paleoclimatology]] attempts to understand the history of greenhouse and icehouse conditions over geological time. Through the study of [[ice core]]s, [[dendrochronology]], [[ocean]] and [[lake]] [[sediment]]s ([[varve]]), [[palynology]] ([[fossil]]ized [[pollen]]) and [[isotope]] analysis (such as [[Radiometric dating]] and stable isotope analysis), scientists can create models of past climate. One study has shown that atmospheric carbon dioxide levels during the [[Permian]] age rocked back and forth between 250 [[parts per million]] (which is close to present-day levels) up to 2,000 parts per million.<ref name="UCDavis" /> Studies on lake sediments suggest that the "Hothouse" or "super-Greenhouse" [[Eocene]] was in a "permanent [[El Nino]] state" after the 10 °C warming of the deep ocean and high latitude surface temperatures shut down the [[Pacific Ocean]]'s El Nino-[[Southern Oscillation]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Huber|first=Matthew|author2=Rodrigo Caballero|title=Eocene El Nino: Evidence for Robust Tropical Dynamics in the "Hothouse"|journal=Science|date=7 February 2003|volume=299|pages=877–881|bibcode = 2003Sci...299..877H |doi = 10.1126/science.1078766|pmid=12574626}}</ref> A theory was suggested for the [[Paleocene–Eocene Thermal Maximum]] on the sudden decrease of carbon isotopic composition of global inorganic carbon pool by 2.5 parts per million.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Higgins|first=John A.|author2=Daniel P. Schrag|title=Beyond Methane: Towards a theory for the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum|journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters|year=2006|volume=245|pages=523–537|bibcode = 2006E&PSL.245..523H |doi = 10.1016/j.epsl.2006.03.009 }}</ref> A hypothesis noted for this negative drop of isotopes could be the increase of [[methane hydrate]]s, the trigger for which remains a mystery. This increase of [[Atmospheric methane|methane in the atmosphere]], which happens to be a potent, but short-lived greenhouse gas, increased the global temperatures by 6 °C with the assistance of the less potent carbon dioxide.{{citation needed|date=June 2012}}
==List of Icehouse and Greenhouse Periods==
* A greenhouse period ran from 4.6 to 2.4 billion years ago. * [[Huronian|Huronian Glaciation]] - an icehouse period that ran from 2.4 billion years ago to 2.1 billion years ago * A greenhouse period ran from 2.1 billion to 720 million years ago. * [[Cryogenian]] - an icehouse period that ran from 720 to 635 million years ago, at times the entire Earth was frozen over * A greenhouse period ran from 635 million years ago to 450 million years ago. * [[Andean-Saharan glaciation]] - an icehouse period that ran from 450 to 420 million years ago * A greenhouse period ran from 420 million years ago to 360 million years ago. * [[Karoo Ice Age|Late Paleozoic Ice Age]] - an icehouse period that ran from 360 to 260 million years ago * A greenhouse period ran from 260 million years ago to 33.9 million years ago * [[Late Cenozoic Ice Age]] - the current icehouse period which began 33.9 million years ago
==Modern conditions== Currently, the Earth is in an icehouse climate state. About 34 million years ago, ice sheets began to form in [[Antarctica]]; the ice sheets in the [[Arctic]] did not start forming until 2 million years ago.<ref name="Montanez-p24-27" /> Some processes that may have led to our current icehouse may be connected to the development of the Himalayan Mountains and the opening of the [[Drake Passage]] between [[South America]] and Antarctica.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Scientists have been attempting to compare the past transitions between icehouse and greenhouse, and vice versa to understand where our planet is now heading.
Without the human influence on the greenhouse gas concentration, the Earth would be heading toward a [[ice age|glacial]] period. Predicted changes in [[orbital forcing]] suggest that in absence of human-made [[global warming]] the next glacial period would begin at least 50,000 years from now<ref name=BergerLoutre>{{cite journal |author=Berger A, Loutre MF |title=Climate. An exceptionally long interglacial ahead? |journal=Science |volume=297 |issue=5585 |pages=1287–8 |date=August 2002 |pmid=12193773 |doi=10.1126/science.1076120 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/297/5585/1287 }}</ref> (see [[Milankovitch cycles]]).
But due to the ongoing anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions, the Earth is instead heading toward a greenhouse Earth period.<ref name="Montanez-p24-27" /> Permanent ice is actually a rare phenomenon in the history of the Earth, occurring only in coincidence with the icehouse effect, which has affected about 20% of Earth's history.
==See also== * [[Atmospheric circulation]] * [[Climate state]]

2 × 1,000 [[Megawatt|MW]] | th_combined_cycle = | ps_electrical_capacity= 5,000 [[Megawatt|MW]] | ps_electrical_cap_fac= | website = }} The '''Guodian Beilun Power Station''' ({{zh|s=国电北仑发电厂|p=Guódiàn Běilún Fādiànchǎng}}) is a coal-fired power station in [[Beilun District]], [[Ningbo]], [[Zhejiang]], [[China]]. With an installed capacity of {{nowrap|5,000 [[Megawatt|MW]]}}, it is the fourth largest coal-fired power station in the world. The station generates energy by five {{nowrap|600 [[Megawatt|MW]]}} and two {{nowrap|1,000 [[Megawatt|MW]]}} units, which is fuelled by [[coal]].[http://en.sxcoal.com/NewsDetail.aspx?cateID=183&id=22537 Guodian Beilun coal power station becomes the largest in China]http://www.electricityforum.com/news/jul10/MassiveChinesecoalplantbeginsoperations.html It is also the first power generation enterprise in China to use [[World Bank]] loans for construction. == See also == {{Portal|China|Energy}} * [[List of coal power stations]] * [[List of largest power stations in the world]] * [[List of power stations in China]] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Coal-fired power stations in China]] [[Category:Power stations in Zhejiang]] {{PRChina-powerstation-stub}}

{{update|date=October 2017}} The '''history of photovoltaic growth''' includes previous forecast and annual deployment figures by country. == Deployment reports == Most PV deployment figures in this article are provided by the European Photovoltaic Industry Association in the "Global Outlook for Photovoltaics" report, the ''Observatoire des énergies renouvelables'' or EurObserv'ER's "Photovoltaic Barometer" report, and the IEA-PVPS (photovoltaic power systems) "Snapshot" and "Trends" report. [[File:Europe WattPerCapita animated sequence 1992-2014.gif|thumb|History of European PV deployment in ''watts per capita'' since 1992. {| style="width: 100%; font-size: 0.8em;" |- | valign=top | {{legend|#C5C5C5|border=1px solid #9E9E9E|<0.1, n/a}} {{legend|#F4E3D7|border=1px solid #E5B99A|0.1–1}} {{legend|#E9C6AF|border=1px solid #D99C73|1–10}} {{legend|#DEAA87|border=1px solid #CE7F4B|10–50}} | valign=top | {{legend|#D38D5F|border=1px solid #B46631|50–100}} {{legend|#C87137|border=1px solid #8C4F26|100–150}} {{legend|#A05A2C|border=1px solid #64381B|150–200}} {{legend|#784421|border=1px solid #3C2310|200–300}} | valign=top | {{legend|#502D16|border=1px solid #140C05|300–450}} {{legend|#28170B|border=1px solid #140C05|>450}} |} ]] * [[European Photovoltaic Industry Association|EPIA]] {{hidden begin | title = List of reports - Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics | titlestyle = background-color: #f2f2f2; text-align: left; padding-left: 5px; width: 400px; font-style: italic; font-size: 0.85em; margin-left: 16px; | contentstyle = padding-left: 10px; }} * 2014 – Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics 2014–2018 * 2013 – Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics 2013–2017 * 2012 – Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics until 2016 * 2011 – Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics until 2015 * 2010 – Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics until 2014 * 2009 – Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics until 2013 * 2008 – Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics until 2012 {{hidden end}} :The European Photovoltaic Industry Association (EPIA) represents members of the entire PV industry from silicon producers to cells and module manufactures and PV systems installers to PV electricity generation as well as marketing and sales. EPIA releases its annual ''Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics'' report in May/June. * PV-Barometer {{hidden begin | title = List of reports - Photovoltaic Barometer report | titlestyle = background-color: #f2f2f2; text-align: left; padding-left: 5px; width: 400px; font-style: italic; font-size: 0.85em; margin-left: 16px; | contentstyle = padding-left: 10px; }} * 2015 – figures for year 2013 and 2014 * 2014 – figures for year 2012 and 2013 * 2013 – figures for year 2011 and 2012 * 2012 – figures for year 2010 and 2011 * 2011 – figures for year 2009 and 2010 * 2010 – figures for year 2008 and 2009 {{hidden end}} :EUROBSER'VER (''{{lang|fr|Observatoire des énergies renouvelables}}'') was set up in 1980, and is composed of engineers and experts releasing the ''Photovoltaic Barometer'' report containing early, year-end PV deployment figures for the 28 member states of the European Union.eurobserv-er.org [http://www.eurobserv-er.org/observer.asp EUROBSER'VER - Observatoire des énergies renouvelables] Eurobserver works closely together with several French ministries and is co-founded by the European Commission's IEE programm.ec.europa.eu [http://ec.europa.eu/energy/intelligent/ European Commission Energy Intelligent Energy Europe] *[[IEA-PVPS]] {{hidden begin | title = List of reports - PVPS Snapshot of Global PV ''and'' Trends | titlestyle = background-color: #f2f2f2; text-align: left; padding-left: 5px; width: 400px; font-style: italic; font-size: 0.85em; margin-left: 16px; | contentstyle = padding-left: 10px; }} * 2015 – Snapshot of Global PV 1992-2014 * 2014 – Trends 2014 in Photovoltaic Applications – Survey report of selected IEA countries between 1992 and 2013 * 2014 – Snapshot of Global PV 1992-2013 * 2014 – Trends 2013 in Photovoltaic Applications – Survey report of selected IEA countries between 1992 and 2012 * 2013 – Snapshot of Global PV 1992-2012 * 2011 – Trends in Photovoltaic Applications – Survey report of selected IEA countries between 1992 and 2010 * 2010 – Trends in Photovoltaic Applications – Survey report of selected IEA countries between 1992 and 2009 * 2009 – Trends in Photovoltaic Applications – Survey report of selected IEA countries between 1992 and 2008 * 2007 – Trends in Photovoltaic Applications – Survey report of selected IEA countries between 1992 and 2006 {{hidden end}} :The [[International Energy Agency|IEA]] Photovoltaic Power Systems Programme (PVPS) is one of the collaborative R&D agreements established within the IEA and, since its establishment in 1993, the PVPS participants have been conducting a variety of joint projects in the application of photovoltaic conversion of solar energy into electricity. Its annual "Snapshot" report is released in early April and provides the first and detailed figures of worldwide PV-deployment of the previous year. An overview of all international statistics PDF reports since 1995 can be found on IEA-PVPS' [http://www.iea-pvps.org/index.php?id=92 Statistic Reports] website. {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="width: 650px; font-size: 0.9em; margin: 1px auto;" |+ Timeline of reported global PV capacity |- ! % |- ! colspan=3 style="background: #cae1ff;" | Added 2014 (MW) ! colspan=4 style="background: #ffdead;" | Total 2014 (MW) ! colspan=2 style="background: #b2e5cd;" | Generation 2014 |} {{hidden end}} ;2013 {{hidden begin |title=2013 – Year-end PV capacity by country in MW |titlestyle=font-size: 1.15em; padding: 5px 5px 5px 115px; text-align: left; border: 1px #b2b2b2 solid; background-color: #f2f2f2; |expanded= |style=width: 94%; margin-left: 19px; }} ;Worldwide In 2013, worldwide deployment of solar PV amounted to almost 40 GW (39,953 MW)—an increase of about 35 percent over the previous year. Cumulated capacity increased by 38 percent to more than 139 GW. This is sufficient to generate at least 160 [[terawatt-hour]]s (TWh) or 0.85 percent of the world's total [[electricity consumption]] of 18,400 TWh.{{rp|5,13}}{{rp|9}} {{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption =Cumulative PV capacity by region in 2013{{rp|17}} | other = | label1 =Europe | value1 =58.7 | color1 =forestgreen | label2 =APAC | value2 =15.8 | color2 =orange | label3 =China | value3 =13.4 | color3 =#de2821 | label4 =North America | value4 =9.9 | color4 =#2E5CB8 | label5 =MEA | value5 =0.7 | color5 =yellow | label6 =Rest of the World | value6 =1.5 | color6 =#666666 }} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 0.9em;" |+ Worldwide installed capacity in 2013 |- ! Report !! Cumulative (MWp) !! Installed (MWp) !! Release date !! Type !! Ref |- | IEA-PVPS snapshot || align=right | >134,000 || align=right | >36,900 || April 2014 || preliminary figures || {{rp|14}} |- | EPIA outlook || align=right | 138,856 || align=right | 38,352 || June 2014 || detailed figures ||{{rp|24}} |- | IEA-PVPS trends || align=right | 139,795 || align=right | 39,953 || October 2014 || final figures || {{rp|34}} |}
An uncertainty in Chinese deployment was the reason for a significant discrepancy between EPIA's ''outlook'' and IEA's ''Trends'' reports. EPIA did not take 1.1 GW of additional Chinese deployment into account, since at the time it was unsure whether these installations were connected to the grid.{{rp|5}} In IEA's final ''Trends'' report, the confirmed figures not only raised domestic Chinese deployment from 11.8 GW to 12.92 GW, but also contributed to increase global figures to almost 40 GW.
; Regions In 2013, Asia has been the fastest growing region, with China and Japan accounting for 49% of worldwide deployment. About a quarter has been installed in Europe (10,975 MW). The remaining quarter of the 38,400 MW deployed in 2013 is split between North America and other countries. Europe is still the most developed region with a cumulative capacity of 81.5 GW, about 59 percent of the global total, followed by the [[Asia-Pacific]] region (APAC), including countries such as Japan, India and Australia with 22 GW or about 16 percent of worldwide cumulative capacity (due to its significance, China is excluded from the APAC region in all PV statistics and listed separately). European solar PV now covers 3 percent of the electricity demand and 6 percent of the peak electricity demand. However, deployment in Europe has slowed down by half compared to the record year of 2011, and will most likely continue to decrease. This is mainly due to the strong decline of new installations in Germany and Italy.{{rp|18}} Cumulative capacity in the MEA (Middle East and Africa) region and ROW (rest of the world) accounted for less than 3 GW or about 2.2% of the global total. A great untapped potential remains for many of these countries, especially in the Sunbelt.{{rp|19,23}} ;Countries {{Pie chart | thumb = right |width = 300px | caption =Added PV capacity by country in 2013{{rp|33–34}}Percentage figures based on "IEA-PVPS Trends 2014" report. Worldwide PV installations of 39,953 MW corresponds to 100% in the pie-chart. See table "2013—Global PV Capacity by Country in MW" for absolute figures. | other = | label1 =[[Solar power in China|China]] & Taiwan | value1 =32.8 | color1 =#de2821 | label2 =[[Solar power in Japan|Japan]] | value2 =17.4 | color2 =pink | label3 =[[Solar power in the United States|United States]] | value3 =11.9 | color3 =#3366CC | label4 =[[Solar power in Canada|Canada]] | value4 =1.1 | color4 =#850AFF | label5 =[[Solar power in Germany|Germany]] | value5 =8.3 | color5 =#8C8C22 | label6 =[[Solar power in Italy|Italy]] | value6 =4.1 | color6 =#B3CC33 | label7 =[[Solar power in the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]] | value7 =3.9 | color7 = #54C571 | label8 =[[Solar power in the European Union|Rest of Europe]] | value8 =11.9 | color8 =forestgreen | label9 =[[Solar power in India|India]] | value9 =2.8 | color9 =#FFF380 | label10 =[[Solar power in Australia|Australia]] | value10 =2.0 | color10 =#CC6600 | label11 =South Korea | value11 =1.1 | color11 =#fff | label12 =[[Solar power in Thailand|Thailand]] | value12 =1.1 | color12 =#FF6600 | label13 =Rest of the World | value13 =1.6 | color13 =#555 }} In 2013, the world's top installer were [[Solar power in China|China]] (+12.92 GW), followed by [[Solar power in Japan|Japan]] (+6.97 GW) and the [[Solar power in the United States|United States]] (+4.75 GW), while Germany remained the world's largest overall producer of power from solar PV, with a total capacity around 36 GW and contributing 5.7% to its net electricity consumption. Italy met more than 7% of its electricity demands with solar PV, thus leading the world in that respect. {| style="max-width: 600px;" |+ '''Top 10 PV countries of Year 2013 in (MW)''' |- style="background-color: none;" | align=center | {| class="wikitable" style="width: 240px; margin: 5px 0 0 5px;" ! (A) '''Data sources''' ([[Nameplate capacity]] in [[watt-peak AC|DC-output not AC]]): * [[International Energy Agency|IEA]]-[[International Energy Agency#Promotion of renewable energy|PVPS]] — Trends 2014 in Photovoltaic Applications{{rp|33–34}} * [[European Photovoltaic Industry Association|EPIA]] — Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics 2014–2018{{rp|24}} * Find additional or alternative information in column ''source'' of corresponding record |} In 2013, Europe added 11 gigawatts of new PV installation (including non-EU countries). It is still the most developed region with a cumulated total of 81.5 GW, about 59 percent of the worldwide installed capacity. Solar PV now covers 3 percent of the electricity demand and 6 percent of the peak electricity demand. However, European PV deployment has slowed down by half compared to the record year of 2011, and will most likely continue to decrease. This is mainly due to the strong decline of new installations in Germany and Italy. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 95%; text-align: right; font-size: 0.9em; margin: 1px auto;" ! colspan=10 style="font-size: 1.1em; padding: 5px 5px 5px 120px; text-align: left;" | Photovoltaic Barometer report – PV capacity in the European Union in 2013{{rp|5–7,9}} |- ! rowspan=2 data-sort-type="text" | Country ! colspan=3 style="background: #cae1ff;" | Added 2013 (MW) ! colspan=4 style="background: #ffdead;" | Total 2013 (MW) ! colspan=2 style="background: #b2e5cd;" | Generation 2013 |- ! style="background-color: #cae1ff;" data-sort-type="number" | off-

On grid means connected to the local electricity grid. Δ means the amount installed during the previous year. Σ means the total amount installed. Wp/capita refers to the ratio of total installed capacity divided by total population, or total installed Wp per person. Module price is average installed price, in Euros. kW·h/kWp·yr indicates the range of insolation to be expected. While National Report(s) may be cited as source(s) within an International Report, any contradictions in data are resolved by using only the most recent report's data. Exchange rates represent the 2006 annual average of daily rates (OECD Main Economic Indicators June 2007).
Module Price: Lowest:2.5 EUR/Wp (2.83 USD/Wp) in Germany 2003. revision.text:
{{Advert|date=May 2016}}
[[Image:US006758018-004.gif|thumb|The nail, as shown in the patent document.]] The '''HurriQuake''' nail is a construction [[nail (fastener)|nail]] designed by Ed Sutt for [[Bostitch]], a division of [[Stanley Works]], and patented in 2004. The features of the nail are designed primarily to provide more structural integrity for a building, especially against the forces of [[hurricane]]s and [[earthquake]]s.
==Features == [[Image:US006758018-005.gif|thumb|Detail of the barbed rings on the shank.]] Starting at the bottom of the nail, the ring shanks on the lower half of the nail are enhanced with angular barbs, which add maximum resistance to the nail being pulled out. The middle of the nail has no extra features, which leaves the section most likely to be damaged during an earthquake thicker and least prone to damage. The area directly below the head of the nail features a spiral-style shank used to enhance the nail's strength in holding boards together. This enhancement keeps boards that are nailed together from moving around under nature's forces and overall weakening the joints. The final feature of this nail is the nail head, which is 25% larger than the average, allowing it to be more resistant to being pulled completely through attached pieces of wood.<ref name= "pop-sci-nov06-41">{{Citation | surname=Unknown| given=Unknown | title=Best of What's New 2006 — Home Tech | url=http://www.popsci.com/popsci/flat/bown/2006/product_75.html | journal=Popular Science |volume=269 |issue=6 | year=2006 | page=41}}</ref>
==Design==
===Pre-development=== The nail's design began when its inventor, [[civil engineering|civil engineer]] Ed Sutt, traveled to the [[Caribbean]] in the wake of [[Hurricane Marilyn]]. Sutt's trip to the Caribbean was part of a team examining the wreckage of the 80% of the island's homes and business that had been destroyed in the hurricane's winds of 95 mph (155 km/h). The finding among the homes that had been destroyed was that wood failure was not the cause of destruction; instead, the findings showed that the nails holding the wood together had failed, leading to the buildings' ultimate collapse.<ref name= "pop-sci-nov06-106">{{Citation | surname=Clynes| given=Tom | title= Dr. Nail vs. the Monster | url= http://www.popsci.com/popsci/flat/bown/2006/innovator_5.html | journal= Popular Science |volume=269 |issue=6 | year=2006 | page=106}}</ref> Sutt's research began after taking a research assistantship program at the [[Clemson Wind Load Test Facility]], which had received funding through a grant from [[Federal Emergency Management Agency|FEMA]]. The grant was used to research wooden-framed structures and the relationship of their failure to wind velocity.<ref name= "pop-sci-nov06-107">{{Citation | surname=Clynes| given=Tom | title=Dr. Nail vs. the Monster | journal=Popular Science |volume=269 |issue=6 | year=2006 | page=107}}</ref> The outcome of the project's research showed that the best way to strengthen a structure was to improve the fasteners that held the [[roof]]ing and wall sheathing to the internal frame, and with this information Sutt signed on as a fastener engineer for the Stanley subsidiary, [[Bostitch]].<ref name= "pop-sci-nov06-107 – 8">{{Citation | surname=Clynes| given=Tom | title= Dr. Nail vs. the Monster | journal=Popular Science |volume=269 |issue=6 | year=2006 | pages=107–8}}</ref>
===Development=== As development began on the nail, there were three major causes of failure to be overcome. These were having the nail — head and all — rip through the sheathing, having the entire nail pull out of the frame, and having the nail's midsection snap under stress. Early research showed that the larger the head, the less chance there was of the nail being ripped through the sheathing. However, the difficult task was increasing the nail's head while still making it compatible with popular [[nail gun]] models. After finding the ideal nail head size, the next task to conquer was preventing the entire nail from pulling out of the frame. This was overcome by adding barbed ring shanks around the lower portion of the nail. During the testing of the shanks, it was noted that above a certain point the shanks no longer strengthened the nail but instead weakened the nail by making it more susceptible to shearing. The final touch to the original prototype was a special high-carbon alloy designed by a [[metallurgy|metallurgist]] that had the perfect combination of stiffness and pliability, giving it the highest possible strength.<ref name="pop-sci-nov06-108">{{Citation | surname=Clynes| given=Tom | title =Dr. Nail vs. the Monster | journal=Popular Science |volume=269 |issue=6 | year=2006 | page= 108}}</ref>
===Sheather plus and beyond=== After analyzing hundreds of designs, and finally coming up with what was believed to be the best design, Bostich finally released the nail in 2005 and labeled it the Sheather Plus.<ref name= "pop-sci-nov06-108 – 9">{{Citation | surname=Clynes| given=Tom | title= Dr. Nail vs. the Monster | journal=Popular Science |volume=269 |issue=6 | year=2006 | pages=108–9}}</ref> Even though the new nail was stronger than most nails, the barbs, which added the much needed strength to the nail's holding power, weakened the strength of the joint by opening the hole too far. This caused the joint to be sloppy and wobbly, so the team went back to the drawing board where the final feature was added to the nail. To compensate for the extra width of the nail hole, due to the ring shanks, Sutt decided to add a thicker screw-shank to the portion of the nail directly under the head. This addition thickened the top portion of the nail giving it a tighter joint, as well as enhancing its overall holding power.<ref name="pop-sci-nov06-109">{{Citation | surname=Clynes| given=Tom | title=Dr. Nail vs. the Monster | journal=Popular Science |volume=269 |issue=6 | year=2006 | page=109}}</ref>
==Testing== Independent tests of the nail's stretch were conducted by several organizations, including [[Florida International University]] and the [[International Code Council]]. Those tests confirmed what the researchers at Bostitch had claimed, that they had created a better nail. Among all of the different tests, it was found that the new nail had twice the "uplift capacity" of other power driven nails, as well as increasing a home's resistance to wind and increasing earthquake resistance by up to 50%. For further testing, Sutt asked for the assistance of Scott Schiff, the coordinator of the graduate program in civil engineering and engineering mechanics at [[Clemson University]]. Tests at the Clemson Wind Load Test Facility confirmed what had already been stated.<ref name="pop-sci-nov06-109"/> With equipment to simulate the force of winds, roofs attached with traditional nails were pulled apart at around 13,500 pounds of force (60.1 [[Newton (unit)|kN]]). At forces up to 16,000 pounds (71 kN), walls built with the HurriQuake environment nail showed minimal wall movement. As the pressure increased to 17,000 pounds (75 kN), then 18,000 (80 kN), then 19,000 (85 kN), the walls began to make creaking and groaning noises but they still stayed attached. As the test rig pushed 20,000 pounds (89 kN), the maximum it was capable of testing, it gave out, showing that the HurriQuake environment nail sustained 20,000 pounds of force (89 kN) and still was not sheared or completely pulled out.<ref name= "pop-sci-nov06-134">{{Citation | surname=Clynes| given=Tom | title= Dr. Nail vs. the Monster | journal=Popular Science |volume=269 |issue=6 | year=2006 | page=134}}</ref>
==Awards== The Hurriquake won the ''[[Popular Science]]'' Best of What's New 2006 award for Home Technology and was honored as the grand award winner for Best Innovation of the Year.<ref name= "pop-sci-nov06-41" />
==Patent== It is the subject of US Patent 6,758,018, granted July 6, 2004.
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://patft.uspto.gov/netahtml/PTO/search-bool.html "USPTO Full-Text Patent and Image Database"]: Simple search on the USPTO patent database. Enter 6758018 into Term 1 and select Patent Number from the Field 1 dropdown. * The HurriQuake nail was the lead segment in [https://www.voanews.com/a/a-13-2006-12-22-voa5/398156.html a 2006 episode] of the Voice of America's science and technology program, "Our World," hosted by Art Chimes.
{{Woodworking}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nail}} [[Category:Fasteners]] [[Category:Hardware (mechanical)]] [[Category:Tropical cyclone preparedness]] [[Category:Woodworking]] [[Category:Earthquake engineering]]
